author: Pater, Walter

text: thee; only I dare not incur the ill-will of my kinswoman. Depart hence
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: as quickly as may be."  And Psyche, repelled against hope, afflicted
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: now with twofold sorrow, making her way back again, beheld among the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: half-lighted woods of the valley below a sanctuary builded with cunning
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: [81] art.  And that she might lose no way of hope, howsoever doubtful,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: she drew near to the sacred doors.  She sees there gifts of price, and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: garments fixed upon the door-posts and to the branches of the trees,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: wrought with letters of gold which told the name of the goddess to whom
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: they were dedicated, with thanksgiving for that she had done.  So, with
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: bent knee and hands laid about the glowing altar, she prayed saying,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: "Sister and spouse of Jupiter! be thou to these my desperate fortune's
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: Juno the Auspicious!  I know that thou dost willingly help those in
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: travail with child; deliver me from the peril that is upon me."  And as
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: she prayed thus, Juno in the majesty of her godhead, was straightway
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: present, and answered, "Would that I might incline favourably to thee;
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: but against the will of Venus, whom I have ever loved as a daughter, I
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: may not, for very shame, grant thy prayer."
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And Psyche, dismayed by this new shipwreck of her hope, communed thus
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: with herself, "Whither, from the midst of the snares that beset me,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: shall I take my way once more?  In what dark solitude shall I hide me
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: from the all-seeing eye of Venus?  What if I put on at length a man's
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: courage, and yielding myself unto her as my mistress, soften by a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: humility not yet too late the fierceness of her purpose?  Who knows but
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: that I may find him also whom my soul seeketh after, in the abode of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: his mother?"
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: [82] And Venus, renouncing all earthly aid in her search, prepared to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: return to heaven.  She ordered the chariot to be made ready, wrought
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: for her by Vulcan as a marriage-gift, with a cunning of hand which had
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: left his work so much the richer by the weight of gold it lost under
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: his tool.  From the multitude which housed about the bed-chamber of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: their mistress, white doves came forth, and with joyful motions bent
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: their painted necks beneath the yoke.  Behind it, with playful riot,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: the sparrows sped onward, and other birds sweet of song, making known
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: by their soft notes the approach of the goddess. Eagle and cruel hawk
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: alarmed not the quireful family of Venus.  And the clouds broke away,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: as the uttermost ether opened to receive her, daughter and goddess,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: with great joy.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And Venus passed straightway to the house of Jupiter to beg from him
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: the service of Mercury, the god of speech.  And Jupiter refused not her
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: prayer.  And Venus and Mercury descended from heaven together; and as
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: they went, the former said to the latter, "Thou knowest, my brother of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: Arcady, that never at any time have I done anything without thy help;
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: for how long time, moreover, I have sought a certain maiden in vain.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And now naught remains but that, by thy heraldry, I proclaim a reward
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: for whomsoever shall find her.  Do thou my bidding quickly."  And
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: therewith [83] she conveyed to him a little scrip, in the which was
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: written the name of Psyche, with other things; and so returned home.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And Mercury failed not in his office; but departing into all lands,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: proclaimed that whosoever delivered up to Venus the fugitive girl,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: should receive from herself seven kisses--one thereof full of the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: inmost honey of her throat.  With that the doubt of Psyche was ended.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And now, as she came near to the doors of Venus, one of the household,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: whose name was Use-and-Wont, ran out to her, crying, "Hast thou
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: learned, Wicked Maid! now at last! that thou hast a mistress?" And
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: seizing her roughly by the hair, drew her into the presence of Venus.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And when Venus saw her, she cried out, saying, "Thou hast deigned then
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: to make thy salutations to thy mother-in-law.  Now will I in turn treat
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: thee as becometh a dutiful daughter-in-law!"
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And she took barley and millet and poppy-seed, every kind of grain and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: seed, and mixed them together, and laughed, and said to her: "Methinks
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: so plain a maiden can earn lovers only by industrious ministry: now
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: will I also make trial of thy service.  Sort me this heap of seed, the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: one kind from the others, grain by grain; and get thy task done before
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: the evening."  And Psyche, stunned by the cruelty of her bidding, was
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: silent, and moved not her hand to the inextricable heap.  And there
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: came [84] forth a little ant, which had understanding of the difficulty
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: of her task, and took pity upon the consort of the god of Love; and he
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: ran deftly hither and thither, and called together the whole army of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: his fellows.  "Have pity," he cried, "nimble scholars of the Earth,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: Mother of all things!--have pity upon the wife of Love, and hasten to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: help her in her perilous effort."  Then, one upon the other, the hosts
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: of the insect people hurried together; and they sorted asunder the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: whole heap of seed, separating every grain after its kind, and so
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: departed quickly out of sight.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And at nightfall Venus returned, and seeing that task finished with so
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: wonderful diligence, she cried, "The work is not thine, thou naughty
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: maid, but his in whose eyes thou hast found favour."  And calling her
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: again in the morning, "See now the grove," she said, "beyond yonder
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: torrent.  Certain sheep feed there, whose fleeces shine with gold.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: Fetch me straightway a lock of that precious stuff, having gotten it as
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: thou mayst."
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And Psyche went forth willingly, not to obey the command of Venus, but
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: even to seek a rest from her labour in the depths of the river. But
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: from the river, the green reed, lowly mother of music, spake to her: "O
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: Psyche! pollute not these waters by self-destruction, nor approach that
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: terrible flock; for, as the heat groweth, they wax fierce.  Lie down
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: under yon plane-tree, till the [85] quiet of the river's breath have
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: soothed them.  Thereafter thou mayst shake down the fleecy gold from
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: the trees of the grove, for it holdeth by the leaves."
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And Psyche, instructed thus by the simple reed, in the humanity of its
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: heart, filled her bosom with the soft golden stuff, and returned to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: Venus.  But the goddess smiled bitterly, and said to her, "Well know I
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: who was the author of this thing also.  I will make further trial of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: thy discretion, and the boldness of thy heart.  Seest thou the utmost
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: peak of yonder steep mountain?  The dark stream which flows down thence
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: waters the Stygian fields, and swells the flood of Cocytus.  Bring me
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: now, in this little urn, a draught from its innermost source."  And
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: therewith she put into her hands a vessel of wrought crystal.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And Psyche set forth in haste on her way to the mountain, looking there
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: at last to find the end of her hapless life.  But when she came to the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: region which borders on the cliff that was showed to her, she
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: understood the deadly nature of her task.  From a great rock, steep and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: slippery, a horrible river of water poured forth, falling straightway
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: by a channel exceeding narrow into the unseen gulf below. And lo!
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: creeping from the rocks on either hand, angry serpents, with their long
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: necks and sleepless eyes.  The very waters found a voice and bade her
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: depart, in smothered cries of, Depart hence! and [86] What doest thou
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: here?  Look around thee! and Destruction is upon thee!  And then sense
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: left her, in the immensity of her peril, as one changed to stone.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: Yet not even then did the distress of this innocent soul escape the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: steady eye of a gentle providence.  For the bird of Jupiter spread his
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: wings and took flight to her, and asked her, "Didst thou think, simple
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: one, even thou! that thou couldst steal one drop of that relentless
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: stream, the holy river of Styx, terrible even to the gods? But give me
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: thine urn."  And the bird took the urn, and filled it at the source,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: and returned to her quickly from among the teeth of the serpents,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: bringing with him of the waters, all unwilling--nay! warning him to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: depart away and not molest them.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And she, receiving the urn with great joy, ran back quickly that she
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: might deliver it to Venus, and yet again satisfied not the angry
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: goddess.  "My child!" she said, "in this one thing further must thou
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: serve me.  Take now this tiny casket, and get thee down even unto hell,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: and deliver it to Proserpine.  Tell her that Venus would have of her
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: beauty so much at least as may suffice for but one day's use, that
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: beauty she possessed erewhile being foreworn and spoiled, through her
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: tendance upon the sick-bed of her son; and be not slow in returning."
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And Psyche perceived there the last ebbing of her fortune--that she was
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: now thrust openly [87] upon death, who must go down, of her own motion,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: to Hades and the Shades.  And straightway she climbed to the top of an
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: exceeding high tower, thinking within herself, "I will cast myself down
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: thence: so shall I descend most quickly into the kingdom of the dead."
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: And the tower again, broke forth into speech: "Wretched Maid!  Wretched
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: Maid!  Wilt thou destroy thyself?  If the breath quit thy body, then
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: wilt thou indeed go down into Hades, but by no means return hither.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: Listen to me.  Among the pathless wilds not far from this place lies a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: certain mountain, and therein one of hell's vent-holes.  Through the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: breach a rough way lies open, following which thou wilt come, by
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: straight course, to the castle of Orcus.  And thou must not go
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: empty-handed.  Take in each hand a morsel of barley-bread, soaked in
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: hydromel; and in thy mouth two pieces of money.  And when thou shalt be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: now well onward in the way of death, then wilt thou overtake a lame ass
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: laden with wood, and a lame driver, who will pray thee reach him
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: certain cords to fasten the burden which is falling from the ass: but
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: be thou cautious to pass on in silence.  And soon as thou comest to the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: river of the dead, Charon, in that crazy bark he hath, will put thee
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: over upon the further side.  There is greed even among the dead: and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: thou shalt deliver to him, for the ferrying, one of those two pieces of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: money, in such wise that he take [88] it with his hand from between thy
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: lips.  And as thou passest over the stream, a dead old man, rising on
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: the water, will put up to thee his mouldering hands, and pray thee draw
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: him into the ferry-boat.  But beware thou yield not to unlawful pity.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: "When thou shalt be come over, and art upon the causeway, certain aged
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: women, spinning, will cry to thee to lend thy hand to their work; and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: of Venus, whereby she would cause thee to cast away one at least of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: those cakes thou bearest in thy hands.  And think not that a slight
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: matter; for the loss of either one of them will be to thee the losing
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: of the light of day.  For a watch-dog exceeding fierce lies ever before
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: the threshold of that lonely house of Proserpine.  Close his mouth with
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: one of thy cakes; so shalt thou pass by him, and enter straightway into
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: and taking what she shall give thee, return back again; offering to the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: watch-dog the other cake, and to the ferryman that other piece of money
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: thou hast in thy mouth.  After this manner mayst thou return again
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: beneath the stars. But withal, I charge thee, think not to look into,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: nor open, the casket thou bearest, with that treasure of the beauty of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: the divine countenance hidden therein."
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: So spake the stones of the tower; and Psyche [89] delayed not, but
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: proceeding diligently after the manner enjoined, entered into the house
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: of Proserpine, at whose feet she sat down humbly, and would neither the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: delicate couch nor that divine food the goddess offered her, but did

author: Pater, Walter

title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: secretly and shut the lid, and delivered it to Psyche, who fled

author: Pater, Walter

text: therewith from Hades with new strength.  But coming back into the light

author: Pater, Walter

text: of day, even as she hasted now to the ending of her service, she was
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: seized by a rash curiosity.  "Lo! now," she said within herself, "my
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: simpleness! who bearing in my hands the divine loveliness, heed not to

author: Pater, Walter

text: touch myself with a particle at least therefrom, that I may please the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

author: Pater, Walter

author: Pater, Walter

author: Pater, Walter

text: hold upon her, filling all her members with its drowsy vapour, so that

title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

author: Pater, Walter

text: the absence of her he loved, gliding through the narrow window of the

author: Pater, Walter

title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1

author: Pater, Walter

title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: upon the air; and being consumed inwardly with the greatness of his

author: Pater, Walter

author: Pater, Walter

title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
author: Pater, Walter

text: took his hand in his, and kissed his face and said to him, "At no time,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 1
